if this test is running on an instance of Linux
without a display try exporting your DISPLAY variable
to a machine that does have a display before running
the tests.   (export DISPLAY=144.230.1.1:0)  Then all
of the gui rendering will leverage the graphics
capabilities of the remote X Server.

Also you could run a virtual display on the testing
machine.  Something like Xvdm which will let you keep
the tests isolated to a single machine.  In this case
you would still need to export your DISPLAY as above
but would look something like this "export
DISPLAY=localhost:100".

I have tried both of these techniques with java and
they work great!

--- Brian Button <bbutton01@...> wrote:
> 
> My problem is that I designed a Java GUI using TfD,
> and now I want to
> run these unit tests, along with the rest of my
> tests, during my
> nightly build. I'm building on a Unix machine, which
> means that the
> java ui has to connect to an X server somewhere. If
> it doesn't, then
> all the gui-related tests fail, since they can't
> open their windows.
> 
> Has anybody solved this problem before? The best
> answers I can come up
> with are to either separate out the gui tests that
> require a window to
> be opened (anything dealing with geometry it seems),
> or replace the
> visible windows with in-memory windows and see if
> that helps. 
> 
> Any suggestions are welcome...
